question: I've seen a lot of people thinking that Bran will be King in the aftermath of the main story. Do you think this will be the case? I don't think it's good, because of how distanced from humanity he has become as the TER. With him acting all autistic and being frighteningly insensitive to Sansa's rape in the show, that kinda soured me on this possible outcome for him in the books.
answer:
I’m personally unsure, but there’s being named king and then there’s ruling. I really don’t know how the titles are going to pan out when all’s said and done, book or show. When it comes to ruling, I tend to think that book!Bran’s connection to Winterfell is so deep and so timeless that it’s probably not great for the day-to-day minutia of ruling. His perspective’s necessary for the longest term, but I suspect that Sansa will be the one handling most everyday political business in Winterfell at the end.

I’d also ask that you please think carefully about how you use the term ‘autistic’ as a descriptor, and even more carefully about how someone ‘acting autistic’ soured you on them taking charge of anything. Plenty of autistic people can get through the day without being an asshole to people as show!Bran was to Sansa - and many of those who accidentally make such faux pas would be horrified to realise what they’d done. I say this as an autistic person myself.

title: Add Color to My Sunset Sky- Chapter 5
body:
I know I took a hilariously long time to update, but I did it! Here’s chapter 5! Only two more to go until I’m done!

Meera was properly winded by the time she turned down the long dirt path that led to the humble farmhouse. As she drew closer, the sight of the candle light flickering warmly in the windows nearly made her eyes tear up with longing, or perhaps that was just the wind. 

Summer had stayed back looming among the trees. Meera could feel his yellow eyes still pointed at the back of her head. There wasn’t a single weirwood in sight, yet Meera prayed to the Old Gods all the same as she waited on the doorstep. If she couldn’t find a way to get Bran moving again, they’d all be truly fucked.

As it turned out, the farm owner was in fact a woman. Meera hardly needed to explain her situation, she’d said a thing or two about being robbed on the road from the New Gift before the woman, Gillian, invited her inside. 

Gillian remarked that she and her children were headed to Winterfell in two days as well, and wasn’t it lucky that Meera had found them when she did? Meera nodded and smiled and agreed to watch the children while Gillian brought her horses back up the road to fetch Meera’s “husband” and “father”.

That was several hours ago. With the sun long down, almost everyone else had gone upstairs to bed, leaving Bran and Meera alone by the kitchen hearth. They’d had a bit of soup with carrots and beets for supper, perhaps the first truly hot meal they’d had since Castle Black. It had made Meera both drowsy and giddy, and she could tell Bran felt the same way.

On the kitchen table, there was a small bowl of apple vinegar, a brush, and a pair of sewing scissors, which Meera was using to clean and cut Bran’s overgrown hair. After every couple of passes through Bran’s hair, the brush would be so full of dirt and grime that Meera found it quite unbelievable.

“Don’t cut it too short,” Bran said, “I like my hair.”

“I like your hair too,” Meera mused, snipping and brushing away, “But I must be able to see your eyes.” After a final run-through with the brush, the warm brown of Bran’s hair was finally visible, rich and glossy in the firelight. Bran reached up and hummed as he ran his fingers through it.

“Your turn now,” he offered.

Meera settled cross legged on the rug just before the fire. She shrugged off her heavy furs, undid her belts, took off her boots, until she sat at Bran’s feet in nothing but her thin woolen tunic, her tangled curls reaching all the way down to her round tummy. 

They didn’t speak much. Bran’s careful fingers worked the worst of the tangles out of her hair; the brush and scissors took care of the rest. Meera sighed softly, resting her head against Bran’s knee. He swept her hair upward from the nape of her neck, and leaned over to press a lingering kiss behind her ear. Before he could pull away though, Meera’s hand stopped him.

“Right now?” Bran asked, “Are you sure?”

“Get down here Brandon, you started it.”

Bran protested vaguely, even as he slid down to the floor to be next to her. His lips met hers, warm and soft and safe. “We’re in someone’s kitchen,” he whispered. Another kiss. “You’re very perceptive,” she replied. Bran tucked his head under her jaw to bite at Meera’s neck, earning a shiver and a fettered gasp. He laughed into her skin.

“Are we doing it now?” she asked.

“Wouldn’t be too scandalous if we did,” Bran said, “We’ve been saying we’re married so often, I half believe it myself.”

Meera smiled softly. Their front as a married couple was something she reflected on every now and then. They certainly behaved like they were married, and had no trouble at all getting others to believe to too, but what would really happen when Meera gave birth, still unwed? Bran said time and again that she could have the baby at Winterfell, but what would that mean for their future? 

Was she to be Bran’s kept mistress? Meera wasn’t comfortable with that idea; she felt like she had always been much more than that- a protector, a sister-in-arms, a friend, and a lover. Would the nobles of the north understand that if she married Bran? Meera wasn’t stupid. She knew Bran could do much better for himself as the heir to Winterfell.

“You’re thinking about something,” Bran said.

“Yes,” she replied.

“Tell me?”

“Bran,” she met his eyes, “What happens to me and the baby if we don’t get married?”

“I won’t send you away, I would never-”

“I know you wouldn’t,” she said, taking his hand in hers, “But what am I to do at Winterfell? Who would I be to you? Would our baby’s name be Stark or Snow?”

“You know I’d marry you in an instant,” Bran said softly, stroking her cheek, “I’ve known since I was young that who I married was never going to be up to me. I guess it seemed like too much to hope for.”

“I understand.” Meera herself had her own budding marriage prospects back at Greywater- but then Jojen had left home, and she had been chasing after him ever since.

“We could marry and no one could stop us,” Bran went on, “No one could order me not to, not when Winterfell is mine.” He got a faraway look in his eyes, the one that told Meera he was thinking of the things he saw through the trees. “But Robb married who he wanted… and we know where he is now.”

“It wasn’t his fault,” Meera whispered, “He was only trying to make reparations and pay his respects when they murdered him.”

“It was his fault,” Bran whispered, “They were so stupid, Robb should’ve just married Roselyn. He never should have loved Jeyne. How could they be so stupid?”

He shook quietly with breath and tears, and pressed the hand not holding Meera’s to his mouth. Meera felt herself beginning to cry. She held Bran as her own tears ran along her nose.

“Oh Gods,” Bran sobbed, “I can’t bear to think about it, so I don’t, but then I just feel so empty.” It was too easy to forget the horrors that Bran had seen- that he never asked to see, and could never forget. It reminded Meera of Jojen.

Bran cried into her shoulder. “How could they do that to him? How could they?” They held each other until the fire burned low. I don’t want anyone to hurt you, Bran said to her, over and over again, I couldn’t bear it.

~*~*~*~*~*~

The milky winter sun was in Meera’s eyes from the moment she opened them. Light washed over the wooden floor, illuminating the smoking remains of the night’s fire, and a still-snoring Bran. It was the first time in a long time that they’d spent the night within four walls, and the color had already returned to Bran’s lips and cheeks. Meera hoped he was dreaming of something pleasant. Just then, the baby squirmed, and she felt an urgent squeeze between her legs.

“Ugh,” she groaned, pushing herself to her feet. She quickly pulled on her furs and belts, intending to find a bush outside, or perhaps a grove of trees. Suddenly, there was an animalistic yelp from beyond the window. Meera froze. Then came a series of short howls, and the sound of something- or someone, falling and scratching in the dirt. Meera grabbed her spear and hurried out the door.

The commotion was coming from the vegetable patch behind the kitchen window. Summer was jumping and prancing uncharacteristically around a young man who lay belly up in the dirt, yelping with frustration.

“Summer!” Meera called, “To me!” The direwolf paused to look at her with what could’ve been amusement, then bowed his head and made his way to Meera’s side. The young man sprang to his feet with a curse. Something orange and carrot-like dropped out of his pocket.

“Who are you?” Meera demanded. She felt confident with a spear in her hand, and a direwolf at her side. The young man pulled his hat back over his dark hair. Something about his large, grey eyes haunted Meera with familiarity, something she couldn’t quite put her finger on.

“No one,” the man answered, in a woman’s voice.

body:
Request: Ooooh I’m so excited to read your writing! How about a Bran Stark x Fem!reader or Jojen Reed x Reader ( not picky whichever you feel more inspired with) if you won’t mind angst that ends in fluff! I won’t specify so your creativity can flow!

Warning: Angst, Season 8 prediction, so not a spoiler!

Enjoy!

~~~~~~~~~

Winterfell looked tragically abandoned from the outside. Much more haunting than you remembered. You were just a girl when you left, but back then it was bustling with life, and there were so many smiles on everyone’s faces, but mostly from the Stark family.

You were a lord’s daughter, long since passed, but during the time he was alive, you and your family went to visit Winterfell. While your father spoke with Ned Stark, you took your time to play with the children your age. Arya, Bran, and Rickon would run around and play games with you, much to your mother’s distaste. She would much rather have you taking an embroidery class with Ned Stark’s eldest daughter, Sansa. But you figured if Arya can play with the boys, why can’t you? Your family stayed in Winterfell for about a month, and this was during the time King Robert brought his family to pay his respects to House Arryn. However, your family left before the House Baratheon did.

But that was a long time ago. Since then, your entire House had been destroyed… everyone but you. You had managed to escape your family’s home when Joffrey’s men attacked. The young and cruel king had wanted you dead after you laughed at him for crying when Arya’s direwolf, Nymeria, had bitten him. The little cunt always remembered anyone who has dared doubted him in the past. But back then, since you were a noble girl, he couldn’t send the Hound on you, so when he was crowned king, he didn’t waste any time when he sent a small army of ruthless men to your doors.

Your mother died protecting the secret passage she made you escape through. It led into the sewers and you escaped by following that to the nearest river. From there, trudging in filth and dirt and water, you and your torn dress traveled to the closest homestead, which just so happened to be the house of Clan Frey.

Walder Frey was cruel to you and made you a slave of his house. His sons and grandsons did awful things to you, but his daughters and granddaughters always protected you enough so that the men would never so much as kill you. You would stay under the Frey’s “protection” until Robb Stark would one day arrive with an allegiance proposal. Recognizing you, Robb sent you to Catelyn Stark, who immediately cleaned and fed you. Through her kindness, she had two of Robb’s men accompany you to the Vale, where Catelyn promised you that her sister would look out for you.

For a few more years, you stayed in House Arryn’s protection. After Lysa was killed, Petyr Baelish took control of the Vale and sent Sansa away, your only friend when she had arrived there. Eventually, Littlefinger would have you leave as well, but he sent you far away to the city of Volantis. A young woman now, you were at high risk of being sold as a slave, so you cut your hair and wore baggier clothes to appear as a boy. While in Volantis, only one person appeared to recognize you, and that person was Varys, the Mad King’s spider. You heard stories about his schemes and the whispers he always told any ruler he worked for, so you had recognized him, too. Knowing of your family’s fate, Varys offered to have you travel with him to Meereen, where he suspected Tyrion Lannister was already there with Queen Daenerys of House Targaryen. Your past childhood sprung to life at the promise of dragons, so you agreed to go with him.

Since then, it has been quite an adventure. Daenerys kept you close and treated you like a little sister. You traveled with her, Tyrion, and the rest of her court to Dragonstone, where eventually you would reunite with Jon Snow. While he and Ser Davos were there, he received word from Sansa that both Arya and Bran were alive and in Winterfell with her, and immediately you felt ten times lighter. You begged the queen to go with Jon Snow if he were to travel back home, but Daenerys was very protective of you now, and she refused you. Eventually, everyone would sail to the White Harbor and ride onto Winterfell, and as you stood just outside its gates, you felt heartbroken to see it in near ruin.

Walking inside, Jon and Daenerys strode over to Sansa, who was already waiting for them. As all of Daenerys’ armies were inside the gates, they all dispersed to find bedding. But Sansa directed you and Jon to the courtroom, where her other siblings were waiting.

Arya leaped into Jon’s arms first before moving onto you. She was much different than you remembered her, but definitely much better looking like a soldier than a lady. When she cleared the way towards the fireplace, you and Jon locked your sites on Bran.

His hair was much shorter now and he had grown into a strong looking teenager, despite the fact that he was in a wheelchair. His eyes were distant, as he had yet looked away from the fire to meet your eyes. The air around him felt different, and it was almost hard to breathe when you sat across from him.

“Bran?” You called out softly.

Jon stood by your side, gazing down at his brother with concern until the younger Stark boy finally looked up at the pair of you, a small smile that didn’t exactly reach his eyes appeared on his lips.

“Hello, Y/n. Hello, Jon. Welcome back.”

The reunion was cut short since apparently, Bran and Samwell Tarly had something urgent to tell Jon. For hours, the three men were locked away in the room while you stood outside. Eventually, Jon and Sam left, the latter looking worried as Jon was pale as a ghost. Once they cleared the room, you snuck back inside because you really wanted to talk to Bran.

“I saw you at the Twins,” he started with, not even looking up from the fire yet again when you entered the room.

“You saw me?” You gasped, sitting across from him again, “Why didn’t you approach me? What in the Seven Hells were you doing there?”

“I wasn’t there.”

“But, you just said-!”

“I am the Three-Eyed-Raven now.”

You paused, looking at him strangely like he had just grown a third, direwolf head, “The Three-Eyed what?”

“Raven. I can see anything past or present, but not future.”

“Like a warg?”

“Exactly like a warg.”

“Prove it,” you challenged, feeling a small, smug smirk on your face.

Bran didn’t even hesitate, as he looked you in the eye with a faraway look, “You were raped by one of Walder Frey’s men. You were eleven at the time it happened, and he would have killed you after you started to bleed, but his sisters came in and stopped him.”

Your skin became completely pale as Bran told the story, your smile had fallen as he continued, “You were sick in bed for the following two weeks. And the only thing that kept you calm was the thought of being back at Winterfell, going back to the way things were.”

You felt sick, but you addressed Bran’s story with a confirmed nod, “I still wish that.”

“It can’t happen.”

“Why not?” You frowned, clearly not liking this new side of Bran. You remembered him to be a free spirit and always able to make you laugh. He was adventurous and cunning for a boy, but now a young man, Bran didn’t appear to be any of that.

“Because I am no longer Bran Stark. I am–”

“You already told me you are the Three-Eyed-Bloody-Raven,” you snapped, “But I didn’t come all this way just for you to tell me ‘no’ and crush all of my hopes and dreams. You’re my friend, Bran. You have always been my friend.”

When he didn’t say anything, just staring at you with that blank expression, you felt like an icicle was piercing your heart, “Or do you think I’m wrong on that, too?”

“You have always been such a beautiful girl, Y/n, even when we were children, you were much prettier than my sisters. When I had asked my mother about your beauty, she laughed and said that maybe the gods had made you by hand.”

You couldn’t help but blush at what you assumed was a compliment, all the while Bran carried on, “Once I learned how to see, it was around the same time Joffrey killed your family. When I couldn’t see what had become of you, I assumed you were dead. Ever since then, I tried not to think about you. I learned not to feel anything, even when I tried to see how you were doing, where you were in the world, and what you were doing. In time… I learned to stop caring.”

You felt it was hard to swallow as your throat started to swell up, “About me?”

“About everything. Like I said, I’m not Bran anymore.”

As you tried to read his expression, you realized he was right. He didn’t even bat an eyelash at you. He didn’t even care that this answer was clearly affecting you. If he cared, even for a moment, that you were starting to cry, he didn’t show it.

You got up to leave the room, your hand opening the door as a thought occurred to you, and you turned back to the Three-Eyed-Raven, “If Bran were here, would he have wanted to see me?”

What used to be Bran looked up at you, and without skipping a beat, he answered, “Yes. More than anything, he would have wanted to be with you.”

“And if I wanted to also be with Bran, would he come back?”

“No… Bran is dead.”

And you left the room after that, knowing he spoke the truth. But he did give you a little bit of a comforting clarity. If Bran were here, he would have loved you. And you were just going to have to hang onto that. 

~~~~~~~~~

You were a lord’s daughter, long since passed, but during the time he was alive, you and your family went to visit Winterfell. While your father spoke with Ned Stark, you took your time to play with the children your age. Arya, Bran, and Rickon would run around and play games with you, much to your mother’s distaste. She would much rather have you taking an embroidery class with Ned Stark’s eldest daughter, Sansa. But you figured if Arya can play with the boys, why can’t you? Your family stayed in Winterfell for about a month, and this was during the time King Robert brought his family to pay his respects to House Arryn. However, your family left before the House Baratheon did.

But that was a long time ago. Since then, your entire House had been destroyed… everyone but you. You had managed to escape your family’s home when Joffrey’s men attacked. The young and cruel king had wanted you dead after you laughed at him for crying when Arya’s direwolf, Nymeria, had bitten him. The little cunt always remembered anyone who has dared doubted him in the past. But back then, since you were a noble girl, he couldn’t send the Hound on you, so when he was crowned king, he didn’t waste any time when he sent a small army of ruthless men to your doors.

Your mother died protecting the secret passage she made you escape through. It led into the sewers and you escaped by following that to the nearest river. From there, trudging in filth and dirt and water, you and your torn dress traveled to the closest homestead, which just so happened to be the house of Clan Frey.

Walder Frey was cruel to you and made you a slave of his house. His sons and grandsons did awful things to you, but his daughters and granddaughters always protected you enough so that the men would never so much as kill you. You would stay under the Frey’s “protection” until Robb Stark would one day arrive with an allegiance proposal. Recognizing you, Robb sent you to Catelyn Stark, who immediately cleaned and fed you. Through her kindness, she had two of Robb’s men accompany you to the Vale, where Catelyn promised you that her sister would look out for you.

For a few more years, you stayed in House Arryn’s protection. After Lysa was killed, Petyr Baelish took control of the Vale and sent Sansa away, your only friend when she had arrived there. Eventually, Littlefinger would have you leave as well, but he sent you far away to the city of Volantis. A young woman now, you were at high risk of being sold as a slave, so you cut your hair and wore baggier clothes to appear as a boy. While in Volantis, only one person appeared to recognize you, and that person was Varys, the Mad King’s spider. You heard stories about his schemes and the whispers he always told any ruler he worked for, so you had recognized him, too. Knowing of your family’s fate, Varys offered to have you travel with him to Meereen, where he suspected Tyrion Lannister was already there with Queen Daenerys of House Targaryen. Your past childhood sprung to life at the promise of dragons, so you agreed to go with him.

Since then, it has been quite an adventure. Daenerys kept you close and treated you like a little sister. You traveled with her, Tyrion, and the rest of her court to Dragonstone, where eventually you would reunite with Jon Snow. While he and Ser Davos were there, he received word from Sansa that both Arya and Bran were alive and in Winterfell with her, and immediately you felt ten times lighter. You begged the queen to go with Jon Snow if he were to travel back home, but Daenerys was very protective of you now, and she refused you. Eventually, everyone would sail to the White Harbor and ride onto Winterfell, and as you stood just outside its gates, you felt heartbroken to see it in near ruin.

Walking inside, Jon and Daenerys strode over to Sansa, who was already waiting for them. As all of Daenerys’ armies were inside the gates, they all dispersed to find bedding. But Sansa directed you and Jon to the courtroom, where her other siblings were waiting.

Arya leaped into Jon’s arms first before moving onto you. She was much different than you remembered her, but definitely much better looking like a soldier than a lady. When she cleared the way towards the fireplace, you and Jon locked your sites on Bran.

His hair was much shorter now and he had grown into a strong looking teenager, despite the fact that he was in a wheelchair. His eyes were distant, as he had yet looked away from the fire to meet your eyes. The air around him felt different, and it was almost hard to breathe when you sat across from him.

“Bran?” You called out softly.

Jon stood by your side, gazing down at his brother with concern until the younger Stark boy finally looked up at the pair of you, a small smile that didn’t exactly reach his eyes appeared on his lips.

“Hello, Y/n. Hello, Jon. Welcome back.”

The reunion was cut short since apparently, Bran and Samwell Tarly had something urgent to tell Jon. For hours, the three men were locked away in the room while you stood outside. Eventually, Jon and Sam left, the latter looking worried as Jon was pale as a ghost. Once they cleared the room, you snuck back inside because you really wanted to talk to Bran.

“I saw you at the Twins,” he started with, not even looking up from the fire yet again when you entered the room.

“You saw me?” You gasped, sitting across from him again, “Why didn’t you approach me? What in the Seven Hells were you doing there?”

“I wasn’t there.”

“But, you just said-!”

“I am the Three-Eyed-Raven now.”

You paused, looking at him strangely like he had just grown a third, direwolf head, “The Three-Eyed what?”

“Raven. I can see anything past or present, but not future.”

“Like a warg?”

“Exactly like a warg.”

“Prove it,” you challenged, feeling a small, smug smirk on your face.

Bran didn’t even hesitate, as he looked you in the eye with a faraway look, “You were raped by one of Walder Frey’s men. You were eleven at the time it happened, and he would have killed you after you started to bleed, but his sisters came in and stopped him.”

Your skin became completely pale as Bran told the story, your smile had fallen as he continued, “You were sick in bed for the following two weeks. And the only thing that kept you calm was the thought of being back at Winterfell, going back to the way things were.”

You felt sick, but you addressed Bran’s story with a confirmed nod, “I still wish that.”

“It can’t happen.”

“Why not?” You frowned, clearly not liking this new side of Bran. You remembered him to be a free spirit and always able to make you laugh. He was adventurous and cunning for a boy, but now a young man, Bran didn’t appear to be any of that.

“Because I am no longer Bran Stark. I am–”

“You already told me you are the Three-Eyed-Bloody-Raven,” you snapped, “But I didn’t come all this way just for you to tell me ‘no’ and crush all of my hopes and dreams. You’re my friend, Bran. You have always been my friend.”

When he didn’t say anything, just staring at you with that blank expression, you felt like an icicle was piercing your heart, “Or do you think I’m wrong on that, too?”

“You have always been such a beautiful girl, Y/n, even when we were children, you were much prettier than my sisters. When I had asked my mother about your beauty, she laughed and said that maybe the gods had made you by hand.”

You couldn’t help but blush at what you assumed was a compliment, all the while Bran carried on, “Once I learned how to see, it was around the same time Joffrey killed your family. When I couldn’t see what had become of you, I assumed you were dead. Ever since then, I tried not to think about you. I learned not to feel anything, even when I tried to see how you were doing, where you were in the world, and what you were doing. In time… I learned to stop caring.”

You felt it was hard to swallow as your throat started to swell up, “About me?”

“About everything. Like I said, I’m not Bran anymore.”

As you tried to read his expression, you realized he was right. He didn’t even bat an eyelash at you. He didn’t even care that this answer was clearly affecting you. If he cared, even for a moment, that you were starting to cry, he didn’t show it.

You got up to leave the room, your hand opening the door as a thought occurred to you, and you turned back to the Three-Eyed-Raven, “If Bran were here, would he have wanted to see me?”

What used to be Bran looked up at you, and without skipping a beat, he answered, “Yes. More than anything, he would have wanted to be with you.”

“And if I wanted to also be with Bran, would he come back?”

“No… Bran is dead.”

And you left the room after that, knowing he spoke the truth. But he did give you a little bit of a comforting clarity. If Bran were here, he would have loved you. And you were just going to have to hang onto that.

question: Am I the only one that doubts that Joffrey was behind the assassination attempt on Bran?  I don't deny that Joffrey was a sadistic, murderous little shit when he was alive, but the details of the attempt, the aftermath of the attempt and the motivation for it, don't seem to fit with Joffrey's snobbish, saddistic or boastful personality.  Joffrey saying words to the effect that he is familiar with Valyrian steel does not necessarily tie him to the dagger used in the assassination attempt.
answer:
I have no doubt that you’re not the only one who doesn’t think Joffrey was responsible for the assassination attempt on Bran.

That said, I find the explanation that Joffrey did it plausible.

He ought to have seen it long ago. Jaime would never send another man to do his killing, and Cersei was too cunning to use a knife that could be traced back to her, but Joff, arrogant vicious stupid little wretch that he was…

He remembered a cold morning when he’d climbed down the steep exterior steps from Winterfell’s library to find Prince Joffrey jesting with the Hound about killing wolves. Send a dog to kill a wolf, he said. Even Joffrey was not so foolish as to command Sandor Clegane to slay a son of Eddard Stark, however; the Hound would have gone to Cersei. Instead the boy found his catspaw among the unsavory lot of freeriders, merchants, and camp followers who’d attached themselves to the king’s party as they made their way north. Some poxy lackwit willing to risk his life for a prince’s favor and a little coin. Tyrion wondered whose idea it had been to wait until Robert left Winterfell before opening Bran’s throat. Joff’s, most like. No doubt he thought it was the height of cunning.

- Tyrion VIII, ASoS

Joffrey’s involvement explains why the attempt was even clumsier than Cersei’s own attempts to bump off Robert. The shoddy methodology is what really narrows it down. Most people in King’s Landing would be a lot better at arranging an assassination than that.

As for motivation, sadly, Joffrey needs no motivation other than Bran’s vulnerability. We see that Joffrey is horribly, violently ableist in his interactions with Tyrion. We also know that Joffrey thinks that murder = strength. He probably thought that he was doing Bran, and the world at large, a favour.

Finally, the Valyrian steel comment. You’re right, it doesn’t necessarily tie Joffrey to the dagger. Valyrian steel is so rare and valuable that it does raise the question of when Joffrey handled it…in such circumstances that he wouldn’t boast about it immediately?

There’s also this.

Tyrion was staring at his nephew with his mismatched eyes. “Perhaps a knife, sire. To match your sword. A dagger of the same fine Valyrian steel…with a dragonbone hilt, say?”

Joff gave him a sharp look. “You…yes, a dagger to match my sword, good.”

- Sansa IV, ASoS

When Tyrion hints at a detail of Bran’s murder, Joffrey reacts, starts to say something, and then changes tack. Tyrion was aiming for a reaction there, and he got one.

summary: Apparently there are fans who... don’t think Bran is going to play a significant role in bringing down the Others/White...
body:
Apparently there are fans who… don’t think Bran is going to play a significant role in bringing down the Others/White Walkers??? I’d always been under the impression that Bran’s importance in the War for the Dawn was one of the few plot points most fans agreed on, but apparently this is now a controversial opinion in some circles… especially if it involves him warging into a dragon… or doing anything other than passing on information to other characters, tbh. (Yes, yes I did peer down the r/freefolk rabbit hole last month. Yes, I do regret it.)

Saying that Bran will be important in defeating the Night King doesn’t diminish the role that other characters will play in facing that threat? And frankly, that and ableism are the only reasons I can think of for fans to ignore all the glaring signs of his narrative importance.

I mean, yeah, the TV show has downplayed Bran’s importance to the series—partially because D&D have historically been wary about portraying the more supernatural side of the story (hence cutting things like Dany’s dragon dreams) and partially because I get the sense that D&D didn’t find Bran’s character or POV chapters very interesting—but…

Even from a show-only perspective, this opinion completely baffles me. How can you look at the guy who has been getting a crash course in greenseeing and warging—the guy who has shared Significant Looks™ with the Night King on the show (and that makes it sound like I ship them lol)—and go, ‘Ah yes, Jon and Dany are clearly the only characters who matter in the War for the Dawn’??

I mean, Children of the Forest sacrificed themselves to protect the Three-Eyed Raven and Bran from the Night King in 6x04. The signs of a character having a Destiny™ don’t get much clearer than having actual beings of ancient legend putting that character’s life above their own.

Since we’re talking show-only perspective right now, here are just a handful of GOT quotes that positively scream ‘Pay Attention, Bran Stark Is Important’:

Jojen Reed [to Bran]: “I have seen the only thing that matters… you." 
—3x02: "Dark Wings, Dark Words”

Jojen Reed [to Sam]: “You saw the White Walkers and the Army of the Dead. The Night’s Watch can’t stop them. The Kings of Westeros and all their armies can’t stop them.” 
Samwell Tarly [to Bran]: “But you’re going to?”
— 3x10: “Myhsa”

Meera Reed [to Bran]: “And if we lose you, we lose everything.”
—4x02: “The Lion and the Rose”

The Three-Eyed Raven [to Bran]: “You think I wanted to sit here for a thousand years, watching the world from a distance as the roots grew through me? […] I was waiting for you.” —6x03: “Oathbreaker”

Benjen Stark [to Bran]: “One way or another, he [the Night King] will find his way to the world of men. And when he does, you will be there waiting for him. And you will be ready.” —6x06: “Blood of My Blood”

[/confused & disgruntled rant]

question: We all know that Bran is gonna be instrumental in defeating NK but others don't like thinking about it bc he's a crippled boy rather than a good looking blonde dragon queen...
answer:
Unfortunately this has been a thing in the fandom for so long that even I accepted that only the dragons are needed to defeat the Others. The thing people agreed on is that Bran will be showing Jon, Dany and Tyrion the way to the Heart of Winter where the last fight will take place. Nowadays I disagree.

Bran is not only the protagonist with ties to the ancient people who beat back the Others without dragons, he is being trained by the most powerful human in the world. In the show, he spent the entire season (the few scenes those fuckers gave him) lamenting that he wasn’t ready. If his only powers were warging and seeing the past, then he was ready to face the Night King, if not then he has some learning left. I also think they were holding back on Bran’s importance while pushing the idea that Dany was needed so much so that we can watch her dragon die with ease and the Night King walk through dragon flame and still think Dany was the saviour. We’ve seen Jon fighting white walkers so we assume that he’ll fight and shutter the Night King in a similar manner. The question is, where is Bran in all of this? Is he merely just there to see the Night King coming? Then why have they met on a metaphysical level, why does the Night King sense Bran, why did he try to kill him after Bloodraven died?

It’s because Bran is the true key to humanity winning. People accept it to be Jon and Dany but I think the magic the Children used to turn a human to the Night King will need to be unraveled by someone powerful. I’m also hoping that when it’s all over, Bran can pull back from wherever his consciousness went and become himself again because I am not amused.

summary: Why do you think Bran brought up Sansa's wedding night? She was already convinced he was who he said he was.  It just seemed so...
question: Why do you think Bran brought up Sansa's wedding night? She was already convinced he was who he said he was.  It just seemed so unnecessary at the time.  I mean sure Bran is weird now but making him a unfeeling robot especially towards his family just doesn't go with the Bran I know.
answer:
Hey, nonnie!

I think everyone and their mother keeps wondering why the hell Bran keeps ejecting stupid things out his mouth but it just seems to be the way the writers are handling his character in his new role as the Three Eyed Raven. Although to be honest, even that isn’t much of an excuse because Blood Raven seemed perfectly normal to me, albeit creepy. He didn’t seem emotionally disconnected so I don’t know why this choice was made in regards to Bran’s character. Maybe it will pay off in some unforeseen way. One can only hope. 

On the whole, I’d say they’ve been pretty inconsistent with Bran’s character and I don’t think they have a great handle on his story. We know he will play a huge role in the War for the Dawn but people are scratching their heads at what that could be, aside from him being the Google of Winterfell. Part of it is that they probably want to save the endgame with WW as a huge twist but part, I suspect, is that they’re not all that interested in Bran. 

If you look at Bran’s story line, once he leaves Winterfell and particularly after the NW incident at Craster’s keep, his arc is meandering and confusing, his character is stagnant and he’s used as a exposition device for other stories (namely Jon’s parentage reveal). Bran’s story line in the books is steeped in symbolism, philosophical questions and being played out as a horror story (the Jojen paste being a prime example - one the show chose to eliminate). It doesn’t mesh well with the Ds love for bombast and huge spectacle. 

Now, as to the reason behind Bran’s interaction with Sansa … I think Bran took Sansa’s amused comment as her not believing him and requiring further proof, hence him triggering her PTSD. It was meant to show not only Sansa that he was who he said he was but also show the audience his callousness in talking about that particular experience. It also added to the isolation Sansa felt through out season 7 and that was meant to increase the odds of her siding with LF in the audience’s eyes. On a larger scale, it’s sort of a strange thing but Sansa, the person who pushed for the reunion of her family the most, ends up being alienated from both Arya and Bran. Her only wholly positive relationship keeps being her relationship with Jon, which if Jonsa were to happen, would only increase the deep connection they have. 

Thanks for the ask!

question: Do you subscribe to the theory that the behavior of Jeor Mormont’s raven is explained by Bloodeaven warging into it? And if you do, why did Bloodraven not do more to influence the Night’s Watch? E.g., I think that had Bloodraven established a trusted communication channel with Mormont, he could have provided intelligence, potentially avoiding the disaster at the Fist of the First Men.
answer:
I think it’s definitely possible that Bloodraven is skinchanging Mormont’s raven. It feels like there’s some element of truth to the theory, and it could explain odd events like some of the things it says, or how it got in the kettle, and so on.

As for why Bloodraven didn’t use the raven to influence the Night’s Watch more:

  • It’s a raven. It’s a bird, ffs. It can only say a few croaking words, not complete sentences. Even if some credulous Lord Commander (which Jeor Mormont certainly was not) was willing to believe there was a person with intelligence speaking through this bird… communication is not exactly easy. Croak once for yes, twice for no? Wait for it to scratch out directions in the dirt with its claws? Choosing a yellow kernel of corn means the wildlings are to the north, a red kernel means they’re to the west? It’s frankly silly.
  • (I mean, like, check out TWOW Theon I, where Bran and/or Bloodraven are desperately trying to tell Stannis to bring Theon to the weirwood on the island by the crofter’s village, and all the ravens can say is “Theon, Theon” and “the tree, the tree, the tree”. It’s not clear in the slightest.)
  • If the man once known as Brynden Rivers thought the Night’s Watch was the key to saving Westeros from the Others… he wouldn’t have abandoned them, wouldn’t have left behind his position of Lord Commander to disappear on a ranging and be believed dead. He’s the Last Greenseer now, his priorities are different ones.

Though another reason may that the theory is incorrect… it’s not Brynden talking through Mormont’s raven. It’s Bran who’s in the raven, unstuck in time and reaching out the only way he can. If so, it’s a wonder it ever makes any sense at all…
